# All of Us or None and Ban the Box Movements

Presentation by Rajas Paranjpe

---

- There are currently almost 2 million people in prisons or jails in the US
- Even more people are formerly incarcerated
- Discrimination against formerly incarcerated people is allowed by employers, in housing, and food stamps
  - This includes getting certification for profession such as lawyers, teachers, and electricians

![bg left:40%](https://images.pexels.com/photos/4427506/pexels-photo-4427506.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)
![bg vertical](https://images.pexels.com/photos/257736/pexels-photo-257736.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)

<!-- The US has a lot of people in prison. More than any other democratic country. But when people are punished, it's not just about how many years of prison time they receive. Even after their sentence is over and prisoners are released as free people, they are treated as second-class citizens for the rest of their lives. As you all know, discrimination based on race, religion, and gender is illegal. But discrimination based on a person's criminal record is perfectly legal. -->

---
# Racial Injustice in the criminal justice system
- Where police look for drugs
- Who police stop and search
- Prosecutors can add on a bunch of crimes
- Legal fees and other fees
- Pretty much impossible to file a lawsuit against officials claiming that they discriminating based on race

![bg right:40%](https://images.pexels.com/photos/6077448/pexels-photo-6077448.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)

---
# Impact of excluding people with criminal records from jobs
![bg left:40%](https://images.pexels.com/photos/3760072/pexels-photo-3760072.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)
No place to live + No one hires you = ?

Employed after prison sentence | Recidivism rate over 3 years
--- | ---
No | 52%
Yes | 16%

<!-- Discrimination againt people with criminal records can lead to more recidivism, when people commit another crime after being released from prison and end up back in prison. According to the The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the recidivism rate is dramatically affected by whether or not the formerly convicted person is employed. -->

<!-- Think about the people who want to start a new, law-abiding life as a normal citizen, who end up unable to find any job no matter how hard they try. They might try to make a living in illegal ways such as stealing or selling drugs, and end up back in prison. -->

---

# All of Us or None
> The goal of All of Us or None is to strengthen the voices of people most affected by mass incarceration and the growth of the prison-industrial complex.

Source: https://anewwayoflife.org/all-of-us-or-none/

![bg right:40%](https://images.pexels.com/photos/609771/pexels-photo-609771.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)

---

# Ban the Box
## Goal
Make employers consider applicants without considering their criminal record, and only doing a background check after sending a job offer.

## Purpose
Give everyone a fair chance

![bg left:60%](https://www.worldfinance.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/bantheboxcampaigniscausingstigmabasedonskincolour_feature.jpg)

---
# Fair Chance to Compete for Jobs Act of 2019
Prohibits non-military federal agencies from asking about one's criminal record until after they make an offer.

![bg right](https://images.pexels.com/photos/31736192/pexels-photo-31736192/free-photo-of-iconic-view-of-the-united-states-capitol-in-washington-dc.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)

---

# California's "Ban the Box" law
- Signed in 2017, effective 2018
- Also applies to private companies, not just government agencies
- Employers can do a background check *after* the job offer, but they can only reject applicants based on emplyment on an individual basis and not just reject everyone for having a criminal record

![bg left:40% fit](https://www.patriotwood.com/cdn/shop/products/CaliforniaStateShapeWoodFlag1.jpg?v=1677086421)

---

# San Francisco’s Fair Chance Ordinance
- Employers have to give applicants a copy of the Office of Labor Standards Enforcement’s (OLSE) Fair Chance Act Notice before they can ask applicants about their criminal record
- Cannot judge applicants based on:
  - Infractions (small crimes with just a fine)
  - Convictions older than 7 years
  - Convictions for actions that are no longer illegal

![bg right:30%](https://images.pexels.com/photos/208745/pexels-photo-208745.jpeg?auto=compress&cs=tinysrgb&w=1260&h=750&dpr=2)

---
